section.heading: Unanimous Vote Required.
section.text: A provisional ballot or a vote on a provisional ballot may not be rejected except by unanimous vote of the local board.

para.text: This regulation applies whenever a ballot is not marked specifically in accordance with the instructions provided to the voter. For example, where the instructions call for:
Marking a choice with an "x" in a box, and the voter uses a checkmark; or
Filling in a circle, but the voter marks the choice with an asterisk.
In the situations described in §A of this regulation, the local board shall:
Follow the standards established in COMAR 33.08.02; and
Appropriately mark or duplicate the ballot for tabulating acceptability.
The local board shall reject a provisional ballot if:
The local board determines that the ballot was intentionally marked with an identifying mark that is clearly evident and placed on the ballot for the purpose of identifying the ballot; or
The ballot envelope was unsealed and there is some indication that the integrity of the electoral process has been compromised.
The local board may not reject a provisional ballot solely because the voter included personal identification information in the envelope with the ballot.

section.heading: Ballot Rejection — Multiple Ballots from the Same Individual.

para.text: If a local board receives multiple provisional ballots from the same voter, the local board shall canvass them as follows:
If a single provisional ballot application envelope contains more than one voted ballot from the same individual for the same election, all ballots from that individual shall be rejected; and
If more than one provisional ballot is received from the same individual in different provisional ballot applications, the local board shall:
Count the first provisional ballot cast by the voter that is legally sufficient and acceptable in full;
If no provisional ballots are acceptable in full, count the first provisional ballot cast by the voter that is legally sufficient and accept in part; or
Reject all ballots if none of the voter’s provisional ballots are legally sufficient.
If an absentee ballot and provisional ballot are received from the same individual:
Except as provided in §B(2) of this regulation, the local board shall count the first ballot the voter cast if the ballot is legally sufficient and reject any other ballot.
If the local board receives an absentee ballot after a provisional ballot from the same voter has been counted, the local board shall reject the absentee ballot.
The local board shall reject a provisional ballot that is received from an individual who cast a ballot in a polling place on election day.

Person No Longer a Candidate. If a provisional ballot is voted for an individual who has ceased to be a candidate, the vote for that individual may not be counted but does not invalidate the rest of the ballot.

Damaged or Marked Ballot. If a provisional ballot is damaged or otherwise marked so that the local board cannot determine the voter's intent in a specific contest, the local board shall reject only that contest on the ballot.
Erasures or Alterations. If a provisional ballot has erasures or has been altered or repaired:
For all contests where the voter's intent is clear, the local board shall process the ballot or, if necessary, have it duplicated and processed; or
For any contest where the local board cannot determine the voter's intent, the local board shall reject that contest on the ballot.

annotations.annotation: Election Law Article, §§2-102(b)(4), 2-202(b), 9-402, 9-403, 9-404, 9-406, 11-303(c) and (e), and 11-303.2, Annotated Code of Maryland
